topics.title: REPRODUCTIVE SYSTEMS OF CATTLE AND POULTRY

subsections.title: Reproductive System of Cattle
subsections.content: The reproductive system produces male gametes, whereas the female produces female gametes. The male gametes are known as spermatozoa, while the female gametes are known as ova. Fertilization takes place when the male and female gametes fuse to form a zygote.

subsections.title: Functions of Parts of a Bull
points: Testicles (Testes): They produce spermatozoa and testosterone.
Epididymis (Long Coiled Tube in Testes): Transports sperm cells from the testicles to the vas deferens, helps maturation of spermatozoa, and stores sperm cells in its tail.

subsections.title: Female Reproductive System of a Cow
points: Oestrus Cycle in Cows: Exotic breeds attain puberty at 15-19 months; indigenous breeds at 27-30 months. Variations depend on management, especially feeding.

subsections.title: Factors That Affect Onset of Puberty
points: Type and Breed of Animal: Some animals mature more quickly than others (e.g., exotic breeds).
Genetic Make-Up: Dairy cattle breeds tend to reach puberty much earlier than beef cattle breeds.
Body Weight: Most animals reach puberty when they have attained at least 30-50% of adult weight.
Mating: It may hasten puberty (e.g., in rabbits).
Environmental Factors: Puberty may be delayed due to unfavorable climatic conditions (e.g., drought).
General Management, Especially Feeding: Properly fed and well-looked after calves tend to reach puberty earlier.

subsections.title: Oestrus Cycle
subsections.content: Definition: Oestrus is the heat period for an animal. The oestrus cycle is the period between one heat period and the next. In cattle, the heat period averages 21 days.
points: Egg development is stimulated by oestrogen.
Egg takes six hours in the oviduct before disintegrating.
Oestrogen level drops sharply after egg release; progesterone rises sharply.
Progesterone prepares the uterus to receive the embryo and maintains pregnancy if fertilized.
Sperm can stay in the cow's reproductive tract for 20 to 30 hours.

subsections.title: Oestrus Cycle and Ovulation Periods
subsections.content: Animal: Cow
points: Length of Oestrus Cycle: 19-23 days
Duration of Oestrus Cycle: 10-26 hours
Ovulation Period: 4-6 hours after onset of oestrus

subsections.title: Phases of the Oestrus Cycle
points: Pro-Oestrus (Day 17-20): Marks coming in heat. Follicles grow; follicular fluid with oestradiol increases cilia and thickens vaginal wall.
Oestrous (Day One): Period of desire for mating; follicles swollen; ovum maturing; heat lasts 12-24 hours; vulva swollen and congested.
Met-Oestrous (2-4 Days): Organ returns to normal size; corpus luteum forms, secreting progesterone preventing further follicle maturation.
Di-Oestrous (Day 5-17): Longest phase; corpus luteum fully developed; uterine muscles develop; prolonged if pregnant; else corpus luteum regresses.

subsections.title: Signs of Heat in Cattle
points: Behavioral Changes: Smells other cows, attempts to mount, restless, isolates from herd, frequent bellowing.
Physical Changes: Vulva moist, red, swollen; clear mucus discharge.
Reproductive Readiness: Stands to be mounted (standing heat).
Other Indicators: Loss of appetite, increased urination, slight rise in temperature, decline in milk yield in lactating cows.

subsections.title: Timing for Breeding a Cow
subsections.content: Based on standing heat observation:
points: If observed in morning: Breed late afternoon same day.
If observed in afternoon: Breed next morning.

subsections.title: Gestation Period for Various Animals
points: Cattle (cow): 270-285 days
Goat (nanny): 150 days
Sheep (ewe): 145-150 days
Pig (sow): 112-116 days
Rabbit: 28-31 days

subsections.title: Processes of Reproduction in Cattle
points: Mating: Union of male and female gametes naturally or via Artificial Insemination (AI).
(a) Natural Mating: Male mounts female directly. Advantages: detects heat, cost-effective, induces puberty/oestrus. Disadvantages: risk of inbreeding, disease transmission.

(b) Artificial Insemination (AI): Semen injected into female reproductive tract. Advantages: improves genetics, controls inbreeding, economical. Disadvantages: requires skill, heat detection critical, limited availability.

subsections.title: Fertilization
subsections.content: Occurs when viable sperm is deposited after ovulation, resulting in a zygote (one-cell embryo).

subsections.title: Embryo Development
subsections.content: Early development stage without distinct structures; occurs in uterus.
points: Embryo undergoes differentiation.
Cells (morula) become specialized.
Morula is the group of differentiated cells.

subsections.title: Fetus Development
subsections.content: Advanced stage after embryo development; fetus nourished via umbilical cord attached to placenta.
points: Umbilical cord acts as waste passage to bloodstream.
Fetus cushioned in amniotic fluid for protection and temperature maintenance.

subsections.title: Parturition (Birth)
subsections.content: Process of giving birth with hormonal changes: corpus luteum decreases progesterone and increases estrogen triggering uterine contractions.
points: Signs: restlessness, udder enlargement, muscle widening near pin bones, vulva swelling, mucus discharge, isolation, water bag appearance followed by labor.

subsections.title: Signs of Complications During Parturition
points: Delayed calf after water bag breaks.
Prolonged calving (>3 hours after calf parts appear).
Breech presentation (rear parts first).
Distress with no water bag after hours of straining.
Only one limb appearing after water bag bursts.
Foul-smelling discharge indicating calf death.

subsections.title: Types of Calving Implications
subsections.content: Breech Presentation: rear of calf emerges first instead of forelegs.

subsections.title: Factors to Consider When Assisting a Cow During Parturition
points: Hygiene: wash hands and arms with warm soapy antiseptic water; sterilize equipment; lubricate vulva if dry.
Restraint and Position Check: restrain cow and check calf orientation.
Immediate Assistance and Post-Care: help promptly; treat cow with antibiotics if hands/ropes inserted.

subsections.title: Important Notes
points: Correct calf presentation: front feet first, head resting on feet.
Labor >2-3 hours suggests mal-presentation.
Afterbirth (placenta) is last stage; must be removed if retained to avoid barrenness.

subsections.title: Female Reproductive System of Poultry
points: Ovary: produces ova and hormones (estrogen and progesterone).
Oviduct: transports ovum, involved in egg formation (albumen, membranes, shell).
Infundibulum: catches ovum, site of fertilization if sperm present.
Magnum: secretes egg white (albumen).
Isthmus: forms shell membranes.
Uterus (Shell Gland): forms eggshell with calcium carbonate and pigments.
Vagina: stores sperm and passageway for egg exit.

subsections.title: Male Reproductive System of Poultry
points: Testis: produces sperm.
Vas Deferens: transports sperm to cloaca.
Cloaca: projects to vent opening; during mating fits into hen's cloaca to release sperm.

subsections.content: Measure of acidity or alkalinity of soil.
points: Scale: 1 (acidic) to 14 (alkaline), 7 = neutral.
Affects nutrient availability.
Managed through liming or sulfur application.

subsections.title: Cation Exchange Capacity (CEC)
subsections.content: Soil’s ability to hold and exchange nutrients.
points: High CEC = better fertility.
Depends on clay and organic matter.
